metadata.h1: I Built a Blockchain and All I Got Was a 17 Page Research Paper
metadata.description: I’m currently a college student. Wow, what a time to be in school (so thankful I’m graduating). As it happens, the main focus of this story happened last semester, before all the COVID-19 stuff…

all_paragraphs: I’m currently a college student. Wow, what a time to be in school (so thankful I’m graduating). As it happens, the main focus of this story happened last semester, before all the COVID-19 stuff accelerated.

As a Computer Science major, I’m required to complete a semester course called Senior Research. A very (intentionally) vague title for a class where all they want you to do, is pick a problem you think you can apply CS to, and research a solution. Oh, and let’s not forget the culmination of the project, the paper, and the presentation.

My professor (hi! if you’re reading this), let us get into groups (both for his benefit and ours) based upon project ideas. I’ll readily admit, that I didn’t come up with my project idea, my partner did. However, I did fervently push to build the project that my partner will gladly tease me for to this day. What is this mysterious project you ask?
We wanted to build a voting system using blockchain.
See the project on GitHub here (there’s also a copy of the paper and presentation there if you want to read it).

Well, my partner is very interested in the information security field of tech (and has a passion for political science), and I like a challenge. The idea intrigued me. The challenge taunted me. Indeed I ended up with many sleepless nights and a couple of clumps of hair from the stress.

We decided to use Hyperledger Fabric (HF) to build the project (without Composer). Eventually, due to issues with OS dependent parts of the project, the actual chain became my piece of the project, and my partner worked a bit on a proof of concept Merkle-tree (which I’m sorry, but I still can’t explain how it works exactly).

I spent most of that semester trying to get basic functionality on that chain done. I started over so many times. I sifted through what little documentation currently exists for vanilla Fabric trying to find the answers, troubleshooting to the best of my ability — some of those things being Medium articles, which I’ll link below. That project tried my patience so badly, but I was too stubborn to start over with something less difficult.

As I’m sure many are unaware, the majority of the voting systems/machines currently used today (in the U.S.) have been studied and found to be very insecure. The reasons why aren’t laid out in exact terms. Likely because it’s hard to determine as these machines were built and distributed before they were tested by a third party.
Essentially it comes down to three likely reasons.
So, with the aim of the class being to try applying our Computer Science knowledge to real world problems, why not a voting system?

As the entire premise of blockchain is to be an uneditable, append only ledger, maintained by a network of peers, what better to fix the security issues? As voting is considered a practically biblical process of democracy, no amount of security could be too high right?

The truth of blockchain, is that the amount of security is determined by how many peers participate in the network to uphold the integrity of the ledger. Due to this you still have to meet the requirements of the Byzantine Generals Problem in order to effectively protect the network and the larger the amount of peers participating, the harder it is to fool the network.

So for the umpteenth time, I gave in, started over AGAIN, and used an example from HF directly, and modified the least amount I could get away with in order to make it work. And it worked! We wrote our paper, gave our final presentation, and earned our grade. Suddenly, the project had no meaning anymore other than a strange one-off side project. In the final stages of writing the paper, we even found that the state of Virginia actually has a publicly available (though maintained privately) e-voting app powered by Hyperledger Fabric.

The first reaction was that it invalidated the point of our project. However, it didn’t. Why? Because that was maintained privately for “security reasons.” Ours was open source. The important difference being, we didn’t have any way to research on whether they’d improved the security conditions brought up by research papers we’d found about older — although still currently in use — voting systems. The idea of open sourcing it would hold the maintainers responsible for community found vulnerabilities, as well as source community talent where needed.

In the end I learned something new, overcame a huge challenge, and did some work for myself that I’m still proud of. Full disclosure, I’ve spent my time doing mostly front end development and I’ve been working as a developer/junior software engineer for close to two years now.

My advice to you, new programmer, is that when you get your basics down, challenge yourself. Think of something very challenging, maybe even outlandish, and go through the motions of hitting the wall and starting over. The challenge will force you to discover the depth of your need to solve the problem, or it will force you to give up.

Either way, even if there’s no real, tangible reward — I still can’t take that particular 100 to the bank unfortunately — it will teach you more about yourself and the technologies you use to reach your solution far better than looking through Stack Overflow for the bits and pieces of the solution you’re really looking for.
